title: 113_hr932
content: The Act may be cited as the "Support and Defend Our Military Personnel and Their Families Act" and facilitates naturalization for military personnel. The "Support and Defend Our Military Personnel and Their Families Act" allows military personnel who served honorably in support of a contingency operation to be naturalized under certain conditions. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act extend the required service time for naturalization through military service. The "Support and Defend Our Military Personnel and Their Families Act" includes provisions for timely reunification of military personnel and their nuclear families, as well as relief for immediate family members of active duty personnel. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act allow certain aliens who are family members of military personnel serving in the Armed Forces of the United States to be eligible for immigrant visas. Section 245 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to provide relief for immediate family members of active duty personnel by allowing adjustment of status to lawful permanent residents under certain conditions. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow immediate family members of active duty personnel to adjust their status to lawful permanent residents if an immigrant visa is available, the alien pays a processing fee, and they are a parent, spouse, child, son, daughter, or minor sibling of an eligible member of the Armed Forces. Posthumous benefits are also available for 2 years after the death of an eligible member due to injury or disease. The paragraph states that posthumous benefits are available for 2 years after the death of an eligible member of the Armed Forces due to injury or disease incurred during or after their service. Eligible members are those who have served honorably in active duty and were separated under honorable conditions. SEC. 5. FACTORS TO CONSIDER IN INITIATING REMOVAL PROCEEDINGS AGAINST ACTIVE DUTY MILITARY PERSONNEL AND VETERANS. Section 239 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to provide considerations for active duty military personnel and veterans. A notice to appear shall not be issued against an alien who has served honorably in the Armed Forces of the United States without prior approval from the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary will consider the alien's eligibility for naturalization, record of military service, grounds of deportability, and any hardship to the Armed Forces, the alien, and their family. An alien who has served honorably in the Armed Forces of the United States shall not be removed from the United States under certain conditions.
